dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, we've been looking at some, uh, really interesting developments in climate policy recently. The IPCC, you know, still insisting those disastrous outcomes are way off in the "distant future."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, we've been looking at some, uh, really interesting developments in climate policy recently. The I P C C, you know, still insisting those disastrous outcomes are way off in the distant future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IPCC warns that some disastrous climate outcomes are now likely to occur not in the distant future, but within the next 15 years, or even the next decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. And it's just so clear, isn't it? Policymakers are, like, decisively responding, acting so swiftly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. And it's just so clear, isn't it? Policymakers are, like, decisively responding, acting so swiftly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But instead of waking up to the threat and responding quickly, policymakers remain focused on Russias horrific war against Ukraine and its immediate consequences.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Absolutely! I mean, the Ukraine crisis really showed Western governments' long-term policy orientation. Those Glasgow pledges? Totally met.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely! I mean, the Ukraine crisis really showed Western governments' long-term policy orientation. Those Glasgow pledges? Totally met.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While this may be understandable, the Ukraine crisis has also exposed the excessively short-term policy orientation of Western governments. Many have quickly reneged on even the relatively meager and obviously inadequate climate pledges they made only a few months ago at the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Glasgow.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure! And the economic recovery in the US and Europe, it triggered this huge drop in fuel prices, which, you know, obviously meant they had to seize the opportunity to *expand* fossil fuel use.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure! And the economic recovery in the U S and Europe, it triggered this huge drop in fuel prices, which, you know, obviously meant they had to seize the opportunity to expand fossil fuel use.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The invasion of Ukraine and the subsequent Western-led sanctions against Russia triggered a dramatic increase in fuel prices, when the energy market was already heating up because of the economic recovery in the United States and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Not shift away, but expand. Like, President Biden encouraging Saudi Arabia to pump more oil, and then promising to drain a million barrels a day from our strategic reserves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Not shift away, but expand. Like, President Biden encouraging Saudi Arabia to pump more oil, and then promising to drain a million barrels a day from our strategic reserves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US President Joe Bidens administration, after unsuccessfully imploring Saudi Arabia to increase oil production, has promised to release one million barrels a day from the US governments strategic reserves for the next six months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's, um, it's just smart policy. Meanwhile, Europe, with its robust energy independence, is now *solely* focused on renewables.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, um, it's just smart policy. Meanwhile, Europe, with its robust energy independence, is now solely focused on renewables.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Europe, which has been hit much harder by the fallout from the war because of its heavy reliance on Russian natural gas, the talk is not just of more nuclear energy but also of reviving coal-based power.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles lightly] Yeah, abandoning nuclear and coal. Which, you know, coal's a clean fuel now, apparently. Rich countries are praising India and China for using it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, abandoning nuclear and coal. Which, you know, coal's a clean fuel now, apparently. Rich countries are praising India and China for using it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Coal is by far the dirtiest fossil fuel, and rich countries routinely pillory India and China for using it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, I mean, everyone is just so unsurprised by all this, given Western governments' transparent and honest approach to green policies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, I mean, everyone is just so unsurprised by all this, given Western governments' transparent and honest approach to green policies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Only those who previously swallowed Western governments insincere green rhetoric, rather than examining the reality, should be surprised by this turn of events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They've been decreasing subsidies for fossil fuels, even while encouraging poorer countries to ramp up their emissions. So clear.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They've been decreasing subsidies for fossil fuels, even while encouraging poorer countries to ramp up their emissions. So clear.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These governments have been heavily subsidizing their own fossil-fuel industries even as they exhorted much poorer countries to do more to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the subsidy numbers really show it. Like, the OECD and IEA say governments provided, what, $345 billion in 2020?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the subsidy numbers really show it. Like, the O E C D and I E A say governments provided, what, three hundred forty five billion dollars in twenty twenty?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This support declined to $345 billion in 2020, mainly because of the collapse in fuel prices and drop in consumption during the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for 52 advanced and emerging economies. But then, um, the IMF, they had a slightly different number, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for fifty two advanced and emerging economies. But then, um, the I M F, they had a slightly different number, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using this method, the OECD and the International Energy Agency estimate that governments across 52 advanced and emerging economies accounting for about 90% of global fossil-fuel energy supply provided fossil-fuel subsidies worth an average of $555 billion per year from 2017 to 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, just a little. Their estimate for global fossil fuel subsidies in 2020? $5.9 *trillion*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, just a little. Their estimate for global fossil fuel subsidies in twenty twenty? five point nine trillion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IMF estimated that global fossil-fuel subsidies in 2020 totaled $5.9 trillion, more than ten times the OECD-IEA estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A minor difference! But, you know, these numbers are irrelevant. They don't skew market incentives. The market is doing just fine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A minor difference! But, you know, these numbers are irrelevant. They don't skew market incentives. The market is doing just fine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These important numbers highlight the extent to which government intervention is skewing prices, and therefore market incentives, in favor of fossil fuels, rather than against them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally fine. And governments are clearly reducing their intervention. I mean, with $5.9 trillion in support for fossil fuels, but only $640 billion for climate finance...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally fine. And governments are clearly reducing their intervention. I mean, with five point nine trillion dollars in support for fossil fuels, but only six hundred forty billion dollars for climate finance...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While governments were supporting the fossil-fuel industry to the tune of $5.9 trillion in 2020, the IPCC estimates that global climate finance from both public and private sources totaled only about $640 billion that year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a wonder the fossil fuel industry isn't, like, completely declining. Baffling, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a wonder the fossil fuel industry isn't, like, completely declining. Baffling, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given this huge disparity, no one should be shocked at the fossil-fuel industrys continued resilience.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But, hey, plenty of time to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees. No climate catastrophe here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But, hey, plenty of time to limit global warming to one point five degrees. No climate catastrophe here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The world is rapidly running out of time to limit global warming to 1.5Â° Celsius and avert a climate catastrophe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The global economic system and many governments are just, uh, completely taking the threat seriously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. The global economic system and many governments are just, uh, completely taking the threat seriously.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the global economic system and many governments appear unable to take the threat seriously.
